awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project:  Hinds Community College- Utica Campus Phase II- Establishing a Cohesive Community College STEM Institutional Transformation Academy - STEM-UP Academy
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Hinds Community College-Utica seeks to build on previous successful efforts to facilitate students' transition from high school to community college to four year institutions and to increase their success rate in STEM disciplines. The goal is to assist students in navigating their educational path and to increase retention and graduation rates of students with STEM associate degrees. The project aims to specifically increase the placement of community college students into four-year institutions through academic partnerships with Jackson State University and Alcorn State University.  The project is expected to create a pathway model for student matriculation from community colleges to four-year degree granting institutions which can be adapted and scaled by other institutions of higher education.

The following activities and strategies are designed to meet the project's goals: development of the Summer STEM Academic Integrated Learning Program for high schools students in Copiah, Claiborne, Hinds, and Vicksburg-Warren counties; a College Success Camp for entering freshmen; development of a support and mentoring program to assist students with transfer and enrollment in a four-year university of their choice while providing them with summer research experiences at the Hinds Community College-Utica campus or at participating universities; establishment of faculty professional development programs to assist faculty in restructuring the learning environment and in building new collaborations.  A cyber-mentoring component will be established to continue providing support to graduates of the program once they transfer to a four-year program. The project strategies supporting these objectives are evidence-based and will be monitored and evaluated for effectiveness.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The STEM-UP Academy aims to assist students in navigating their educational path and to increase the retention and graduation rates of students with STEM associate degrees.  The STEM-UP Academy aims to increase the graduation and retention rates of students with STEM associate degrees and assist in bridging those students into four-year institutions to pursue bachelor and graduate degrees in STEM.

  • STEM-UP 2017-2018 Graduates: 82% graduated; 83% transitioned to a four-year institution
  • STEM-UP 2018-2019 Graduates: 81% graduated; 100% transitioned to a four-year institution
  • STEM-UP 2019-2020 Graduates: 78% graduated; 82% transitioned to a four-year institution.
  • STEM-UP 2020-2021 Graduates:  100% graduated; 55% transitioned to a four-year institution.
  • STEM-UP 2021-2022 Graduates:  79% graduated; 63 % transitioned to a four-year institution.
  • STEM-UP 2022-2023 Partial Year Graduates:  100% graduated; 73% transitioned to a four-year institution

It is noted that during Years 2019-2021 (the height of the COVID-19 pandemic), the transition rate of graduating students to 4-year institutions declined.  There are many factors that impacted this decline; it is believed that the worldwide pandemic was one of the major influences that impacted this decline.

Objective 1: Bridges: Create an infrastructure and intentional activities that will channel students into the educational system from high schools to community colleges and from community colleges to universities.

Objective 2: Engagement: Provide a broader variety of opportunities to students, which are available within and outside their home institution and accessible through a variety of media, including cyber-infrastructures.

Objective 3: Research: Support nanotechnology research and research in biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics, and computer science.

Objective 4: Transformational Instruction: Provide professional development and learning opportunities to faculty that transform instruction and restructure the learning environment.

Objective 5: Collaboration: Strengthen existing collaborations and agreements with Jackson State University and build a new one with Alcorn State University.

Objective 6: Intervention Study: Establish the relationship between HBCU-UP activities and students? academic performance and educational trajectory, variations by socio-demographic characteristics, and understanding the factors that advance or hinder academic performance and educational trajectories.

As STEM-UP Academy enters its final year for this reporting period, the recommendations by external evaluators presented an opportunity for both retrospective and prospective examination of the program's goal achievement and attainment of its stated objectives. Successful Cohort graduations and enrollment in Four-Year institutions majoring in STEM and STEM-related disciplines were attained. Students not enrolled in four-year institutions were employed in STEM-related jobs, a positive residual that resulted in successful outcomes.  Hinds Community College - Utica Campus successfully implemented the goals and objectives of the Project as annotated in the listings of students' achievements and the external evaluator's comments.

As a part of this report, STEM UP Academy graduates can be seen in the uploaded image entitled "STEM UP Academy Graduates," holding up their intended college T-shirt.  Students committed to attending Jackson State University, Alcorn State University, Mississippi Valley State University, University of Mississippi, University of West Alabama, and Tuskegee.  Hinds Community College successfully transitioned students through the STEM pipeline from High School through our two-year STEM Up Academy to four-year institutions as proposed in the project.


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Jonathan W Townes
